subject: RE: [junit] Is there a tool which generates JUnit-test stubs?
msgSnippet: Links: Forte for Java: http://www.sun.com/forte/ffj/  Netbean add-in for JUnit stub generation: http://junit.netbeans.org/
messageBody:
Links:
 
Forte for Java:
http://www.sun.com/forte/ffj/
 
Netbean add-in for JUnit stub generation:
http://junit.netbeans.org/
 
Josh
 
 
-----Original Message-----
From: Chappell, Simon P [mailto:simon.chappell@...]
Sent: Friday, March 15, 2002 11:28 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [junit] Is there a tool which generates JUnit-test stubs?

JTest is nice, but I hadn't realised that it wrote JUnit code? Are you certain about this?
 
Simon
 

-----------------------------------------------------------------
Simon P. Chappell                     simon.chappell@...

-----Original Message-----
From: andy chang [mailto:andy0126@...]
Sent: Friday, March 15, 2002 10:25 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Is there a tool which generates JUnit-test stubs?

Yes, you should try Jtest from ParaSoft.  It will automatically generate harness around the class and stub out any external call.  It will also execute the testcases you wrote using Junit and provide you with a coverage analysis.  In addition, it will also generate dynamic test cases for you automatically. 
 
----- Original Message -----
From: markus baumgartner
Sent: Friday, March 15, 2002 8:16 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] Is there a tool which generates JUnit-test stubs?
 

I'm spending a lot of time passing new method into the testclass and write a
"test_" in front of it (and oftenly forget to do it, too).
I made a try to automate the creation of stubs for all existing methods of a
class using the Reflection API (e.g. from myProcedure(int A, String B) to
test_myProcedure_int_A_String_B. The final goal would be to have the tool
comparing the class to the test_class and create stubs for new methods
while leaving the existing ones untouched.

Before I'm going to create it on my own, I wanted to know, if anybody knows
about an existing tool, that does the job?

If it does not exist, is there a good reason, why this automation wouldn't
make sense? Sometimes for complex function you may need several testcases,
but they can be easely created by taking the first stub and append a
number...
